Chemical Equilibrium.question: What is a closed system in chemical equilibrium?
options: A system where energy is exchanged but not matter
A system where both energy and matter are exchanged
A system where neither energy nor matter is exchanged
A system where only matter is exchanged
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: A system where energy is exchanged but not matter

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Which of the following best defines chemical equilibrium?
options: The point at which the forward reaction stops
The rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction
The concentration of reactants is equal to the concentration of products
All reactants have been converted to products
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The rate of the forward reaction equals the rate of the reverse reaction

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the equilibrium position if more reactants are added to a reaction at equilibrium?
options: It shifts to the right, favoring the forward reaction
It shifts to the left, favoring the reverse reaction
It decreases the rate of the forward reaction
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: It shifts to the right, favoring the forward reaction

Chemical Equilibrium.question: How does an increase in temperature affect an exothermic reaction at equilibrium?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the left, favoring the reverse reaction
The equilibrium shifts to the right, favoring the forward reaction
It does not affect the equilibrium
It increases the yield of products
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the left, favoring the reverse reaction

Chemical Equilibrium.question: If the concentration of a product is decreased, what happens to the equilibrium position?
options: It shifts to the right, producing more product
It shifts to the left, consuming more reactant
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: It shifts to the right, producing more product

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Which factor does NOT affect the value of the equilibrium constant (Kc)?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Presence of a catalyst

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What is Le Chatelier's principle?
options: When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts to minimize the disturbance
When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it stays at equilibrium
When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it increases the rate of the reaction
When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it favors the forward reaction
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: When a system at equilibrium is disturbed, it shifts to minimize the disturbance

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In a closed system, the reaction A + B ⇌ C + D is at equilibrium. What happens if the pressure is increased?
options: The equilibrium will shift to the side with fewer moles of gas
The equilibrium will shift to the side with more moles of gas
The equilibrium will stay the same
The rate of both reactions will decrease
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium will shift to the side with fewer moles of gas

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Why does increasing the concentration of reactants increase the rate of the forward reaction at equilibrium?
options: It increases the frequency of collisions between reactant molecules
It changes the value of the equilibrium constant
It lowers the energy of the product
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: It increases the frequency of collisions between reactant molecules

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What will happen to the equilibrium constant (Kc) if the temperature is decreased for an exothermic reaction?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc will increase

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the concentrations of products and reactants at equilibrium?
options: They decrease until the reaction stops
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: They remain constant

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Which reaction condition would favor the production of more products in an exothermic reaction at equilibrium?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Decreasing the temperature

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What is the equilibrium constant (Kc) used to describe?
options: The ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations at equilibrium
The total number of moles of a substance in a reaction
The speed of a reaction reaching equilibrium
The energy required to start a reaction
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The ratio of product concentrations to reactant concentrations at equilibrium

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the equilibrium constant (Kc) for an endothermic reaction if the temperature is increased?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc increases

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Which of the following describes a dynamic equilibrium?
options: The forward and reverse reactions continue at the same rate
The forward reaction stops, and only the reverse reaction occurs
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The forward and reverse reactions continue at the same rate

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the position of equilibrium when a catalyst is added to a reaction?
options: It does not change the equilibrium position
It increases the concentration of products
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: It does not change the equilibrium position

Chemical Equilibrium.question: How does decreasing the concentration of a reactant affect the equilibrium of a reaction?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the left, favoring the reverse reaction
The equilibrium shifts to the right, favoring the forward reaction
It increases the rate of the forward reaction
It decreases the value of the equilibrium constant
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the left, favoring the reverse reaction

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the equilibrium position of a gas-phase reaction if the volume of the reaction vessel is decreased?
options: The equilibrium shifts toward the side with fewer moles of gas
The equilibrium shifts toward the side with more moles of gas
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts toward the side with fewer moles of gas

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What effect does a decrease in temperature have on an endothermic reaction at equilibrium?
options: It shifts the equilibrium to the left, favoring the reverse reaction
It shifts the equilibrium to the right, favoring the forward reaction
It increases the rate of the forward reaction
It increases the yield of products
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: It shifts the equilibrium to the left, favoring the reverse reaction

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In a chemical reaction, A + B ⇌ C + D, what happens if the concentration of B is increased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more C and D
The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more A and B
The rate of the reverse reaction increases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more C and D

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the value of the equilibrium constant if a reaction is exothermic and the temperature is increased?
options: The equilibrium constant remains the same
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium constant decreases

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Which of the following is true about a reversible reaction?
options: It can proceed in both the forward and reverse directions
It only proceeds in the forward direction
It stops once products are formed
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: It can proceed in both the forward and reverse directions

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the rate of the forward and reverse reactions at equilibrium?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: They are equal

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What is the effect of a catalyst on the time it takes to reach equilibrium?
options: It decreases the time to reach equilibrium
It increases the time to reach equilibrium
It has no effect on the time to reach equilibrium
It decreases the concentration of reactants
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: It decreases the time to reach equilibrium

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Why does increasing the pressure in a gas reaction favor the side with fewer moles of gas at equilibrium?
options: Because the system reduces the pressure by shifting toward fewer gas molecules

Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Because the system reduces the pressure by shifting toward fewer gas molecules

options: The equilibrium position is not affected
The equilibrium shifts to the left
The equilibrium shifts to the right
The rate of the forward reaction increases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium position is not affected

Chemical Equilibrium.question: If a reaction has more products than reactants at equilibrium, what does this indicate about the equilibrium constant (Kc)?

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction 2NO₂(g) ⇌ N₂O₄(g), what happens to the equilibrium position when the temperature is decreased?

The equilibrium shifts to the left, favoring the formation of NO₂
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right, favoring the formation of N₂O₄

Chemical Equilibrium.question: If a reaction at equilibrium has more products than reactants, what can be said about the magnitude of the equilibrium constant (Kc)?

The concentrations of H₂ and I₂ will decrease
There will be no change in the concentrations of H₂ and I₂
The concentrations of H₂ and I₂ will remain constant
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The concentrations of H₂ and I₂ will increase

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), what happens to the value of the equilibrium constant if the temperature is increased?
options: The value of Kc remains unchanged

Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts toward the reactants

The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more NO

Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right, forming more NO₂

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the position of equilibrium when an inert gas is added to a reaction mixture at constant volume?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right
The equilibrium shifts to the left

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction A + B ⇌ C + D, what will happen to the equilibrium position if the volume of the reaction vessel is increased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the side with more moles of gas
The equilibrium shifts to the side with fewer moles of gas

Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the side with more moles of gas

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Which factor will change the value of the equilibrium constant (Kc) for a reaction?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Temperature

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction H₂(g) + Cl₂(g) ⇌ 2HCl(g), what happens to the equilibrium position if the concentration of HCl is decreased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more HCl
The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more H₂ and Cl₂
The rate of the forward reaction decreases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more HCl

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the reaction 2NH₃(g) ⇌ N₂(g) + 3H₂(g), what will happen to the equilibrium if the volume of the reaction vessel is decreased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more NH₃
The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more N₂ and H₂
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more NH₃

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction CO(g) + H₂O(g) ⇌ CO₂(g) + H₂(g), what happens to the equilibrium position if CO₂ is removed from the reaction mixture?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more CO₂
The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more CO
The rate of the reverse reaction increases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more CO₂

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), what will happen to the position of equilibrium if the concentration of H₂ is decreased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more N₂ and H₂
The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more NH₃
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more N₂ and H₂

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the equilibrium reaction H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), what happens to the equilibrium constant (Kc) if the temperature is decreased?
options: Kc increases if the reaction is exothermic
Kc decreases if the reaction is endothermic
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc increases if the reaction is exothermic

Chemical Equilibrium.question: What happens to the equilibrium constant (Kc) for an exothermic reaction when the temperature is increased?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc decreases

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the reaction A(g) + 2B(g) ⇌ 2C(g), what will happen to the equilibrium position if the volume of the reaction vessel is decreased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more C
The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more A and B
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more C

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the equilibrium reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), what happens to the equilibrium constant (Kc) if the temperature is increased for an exothermic reaction?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc decreases

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Consider the equilibrium reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g). If the pressure is increased, what will happen to the equilibrium yield of NH₃, and why?
options: The yield of NH₃ will increase because there are fewer moles of gas on the product side
The yield of NH₃ will decrease because there are fewer moles of gas on the reactant side
The yield of NH₃ will remain unchanged
The equilibrium will shift to the left, producing more N₂ and H₂
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The yield of NH₃ will increase because there are fewer moles of gas on the product side

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the equilibrium reaction PCl₅(g) ⇌ PCl₃(g) + Cl₂(g), what effect will decreasing the temperature have if the forward reaction is endothermic?
options: The equilibrium will shift to the left, favoring the reverse reaction
The equilibrium will shift to the right, favoring the forward reaction
The rate of both reactions will increase
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium will shift to the left, favoring the reverse reaction

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the equilibrium 2NO₂(g) ⇌ N₂O₄(g), what will happen to the equilibrium position if the volume of the reaction vessel is decreased?
options: The equilibrium will shift to the right, forming more N₂O₄
The equilibrium will shift to the left, forming more NO₂
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium will shift to the right, forming more N₂O₄

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the reaction 2CO(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2CO₂(g), the enthalpy change (ΔH) is negative. What effect will increasing the temperature have on the equilibrium yield of CO₂?
options: The equilibrium yield of CO₂ will decrease
The equilibrium yield of CO₂ will increase
The equilibrium yield of CO₂ will remain the same
The reaction will favor the formation of more CO
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium yield of CO₂ will decrease

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the equilibrium 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), which change will result in a decrease in the equilibrium concentration of SO₃?
options: Increasing the temperature for an exothermic reaction
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Increasing the temperature for an exothermic reaction

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), the equilibrium constant (Kc) is 50 at 500 K and decreases to 20 at 600 K. What can you conclude about the reaction?
options: The reaction is unaffected by temperature
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The forward reaction is exothermic

Chemical Equilibrium.question: Consider the equilibrium CH₄(g) + H₂O(g) ⇌ CO(g) + 3H₂(g). What happens to the equilibrium position if an inert gas is added to the reaction mixture at constant pressure?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right
The equilibrium shifts to the left
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the equilibrium H₂(g) + Br₂(g) ⇌ 2HBr(g), what will happen to the equilibrium constant (Kc) if the temperature is increased and the forward reaction is exothermic?
options: The equilibrium position will shift to the right
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc will decrease

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the equilibrium N₂O₄(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g), what will happen to the value of the equilibrium constant (Kc) if the temperature is decreased and the forward reaction is endothermic?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc will decrease

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), what will happen to the equilibrium if the pressure is decreased and the number of moles of gas on each side is equal?
options: The equilibrium will shift to the right
The equilibrium will shift to the left
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium will remain unchanged

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the reaction N₂(g) + 3H₂(g) ⇌ 2NH₃(g), what happens to the equilibrium yield of NH₃ if both the pressure and temperature are increased, assuming the forward reaction is exothermic?
options: The yield of NH₃ remains the same
The rate of the reverse reaction increases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The yield of NH₃ decreases

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the equilibrium reaction H₂(g) + I₂(g) ⇌ 2HI(g), what will happen to the equilibrium constant (Kc) if a catalyst is added?
options: The reaction will shift to the right
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc will remain unchanged

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the equilibrium CO(g) + H₂O(g) ⇌ CO₂(g) + H₂(g), what happens to the equilibrium position if the concentration of H₂O is decreased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more CO and H₂O
The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more CO₂ and H₂
The rate of the reverse reaction decreases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more CO and H₂O

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction A(g) + B(g) ⇌ C(g) + D(g), what happens to the equilibrium position if the volume of the reaction vessel is increased and both sides of the equation have the same number of moles of gas?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right
The equilibrium shifts to the left
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium position remains unchanged

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In an endothermic reaction, what effect does decreasing the temperature have on the equilibrium constant (Kc)?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc decreases

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the reaction 2SO₃(g) ⇌ 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g), what happens to the equilibrium yield of SO₂ if the pressure is increased?
options: The yield of SO₂ remains the same
The rate of the forward reaction increases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The yield of SO₂ decreases

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the equilibrium 2NO(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2NO₂(g), what will happen to the equilibrium constant (Kc) if the temperature is increased and the forward reaction is exothermic?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc will decrease

Chemical Equilibrium.question: For the reaction 2SO₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2SO₃(g), what happens to the equilibrium position if the concentration of O₂ is increased?
options: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more SO₃
The equilibrium shifts to the left, producing more SO₂
The rate of the reverse reaction increases
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: The equilibrium shifts to the right, producing more SO₃

Chemical Equilibrium.question: In the equilibrium N₂(g) + O₂(g) ⇌ 2NO(g), what happens to the equilibrium constant (Kc) if the temperature is increased and the forward reaction is endothermic?
Chemical Equilibrium.answer: Kc will increase

Climate and Weather.question: What is the general direction of movement for mid-latitude cyclones in the Southern Hemisphere?

Climate and Weather.question: What type of cloud is commonly associated with the warm front in a mid-latitude cyclone?
Climate and Weather.answer: Nimbostratus

Climate and Weather.question: In which latitude range do mid-latitude cyclones usually develop?
What happens to air pressure as a cold front approaches?
Climate and Weather.answer: It decreases then increases

Climate and Weather.question: What is the impact of the South Atlantic High-Pressure system on South Africa’s climate in winter?
options: It brings heavy rainfall to the interior
It prevents cold fronts from affecting the interior
It causes high humidity in coastal areas
It increases temperature in coastal regions
Climate and Weather.answer: It prevents cold fronts from affecting the interior

Climate and Weather.question: What is the significance of the Kalahari Anticyclone during winter over South Africa?
options: It causes dry and cold conditions in the interior
It encourages the development of tropical cyclones
Climate and Weather.answer: It causes dry and cold conditions in the interior

Climate and Weather.question: What type of wind is associated with coastal low-pressure systems in South Africa?
Climate and Weather.answer: Onshore winds

Climate and Weather.question: Why do mid-latitude cyclones affect the Western Cape more than other parts of South Africa?
options: Due to its latitude and the movement of cold fronts
Because it is closer to the equator
Because of its proximity to the Indian Ocean
Due to the influence of tropical cyclones
Climate and Weather.answer: Due to its latitude and the movement of cold fronts

Climate and Weather.question: What is the relationship between air temperature and altitude in a valley during the night?
Climate and Weather.answer: Temperature increases with altitude

Climate and Weather.question: What is the main cause of berg winds in South Africa?
